titleStmt.title: Synaptic drive in spinal motoneurons during scratch network activity

analytic.title: Synaptic drive in spinal motoneurons during scratch network activity

biblStruct.note: Submitted 7 February 2018; accepted in final form 6 July 2018

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

p.s: Synaptic activity in motoneurons may provide unique insight in the relation between functional network activity and behavior.

During scratch network activity in an ex vivo preparation from red-eared turtles (Trachemys scripta elegans), excitatory and inhibitory synaptic current can be separated and quantified in voltage-clamp recordings.

With this technique, we confirm the reciprocal synaptic excitation and inhibition in hip flexor motoneurons during ipsilateral scratching and show that out-of-phase inhibition and excitation also characterize hip extensor motoneurons during ipsi-and contralateral scratching.
In contrast, inhibition precedes and partly overlaps excitation in hip flexor-like motoneurons and delays depolarization of membrane potential.
We conclude that out-of-phase excitation and inhibition during rhythmic network activity is a common feature in spinal motoneurons.
NEW & NOTEWORTHY During network activity, the firing pattern of individual neurons is shaped by their intrinsic conductances and synaptic input.
Quantification of synaptic input is, therefore, essential to understand how the properties of individual neurons contribute to function and help to reveal the structure of the network.
Here, we show how a combination of recording techniques can be used to quantify and compare the pattern of synaptic activity in different groups of motoneurons during rhythmic network activity.
central pattern generator (CPG); motoneuron; reciprocal excitation/ inhibition; spinal
Locomotion in animals is secured by precisely timed sequential activation of many muscle groups.
A fundamental motif in this complex orchestra is alternation between flexors and extensors.
Mutual inhibition between flexors and extensors (half-centers) was proposed to explain the robust coordination between antagonists (Brown 1914;Jankowska et al. 1965).

The implication is that both flexors and extensors are driven by out-of-phase excitation and inhibition during rhythmic behaviors (Goulding et al. 2014;Grillner and Jessell 2009;Kiehn 2016;Stein 2010).

This pattern of synaptic activity in motoneurons has only been recorded directly in aquatic animals (Dale 1985;Gabriel et al. 2009;Russell and Wallén 1983) where locomotion is dependent on alternating activity between left-right and not flexors-extensors.

Neurons embedded in active networks in other brain areas can be driven by in-phase synaptic excitation and inhibition (Priebe and Ferster 2005;Shu et al. 2003;Wilent and Contreras 2005) resulting in a substantial conductance increase (Borg-Graham et al. 1998;Destexhe et al. 2003).

In line, the high-conductance states in spinal motoneurons during rhythmic network activity in the turtle (Alaburda et al. 2005;Guzulaitis et al. 2016) were suggested to be due to balanced excitation and inhibition (Berg et al. 2007).

However, recent experiments in hip flexor (HF) motoneurons show that synaptic excitation is predominantly balanced by intrinsic outward rectification activated during depolarization rather than by synaptic inhibition (Guzulaitis and Hounsgaard 2017).
In fact, the experiments demonstrated explicitly that synaptic inhibition and excitation peaked out-of-phase in HF motoneurons during rhythmic motor behavior (Guzulaitis and Hounsgaard 2017).

It is not known whether this type of activation also applies for other types of motoneurons and whether out-of-phase synaptic inhibition and excitation remain during different spinal network activities.

In addition, gain and pattern control by in-phase inhibition in motoneurons (Currie and Lee 1997; Heckman and Enoka 2012;Johnson and Heckman 2014;Kishore et al. 2014;Vestergaard and Berg 2015) might be more prominent in other motor pools and behaviors.
Therefore, in the present study, whole cell recordings were obtained from motoneurons in an ex vivo preparation from the adult turtle.
With voltage-clamp (VC) recordings, it is shown that HF and hip extensor (HE) motoneurons received out-of-phase excitation and inhibition during sensory-induced fictive scratching.
In contrast, overlap between excitation and inhibition in HF-like motoneurons was found, i.e., inhibition precedes excitation and delays depolarization during fictive scratching.
The surgical procedures complied with Danish legislation and were approved by the controlling body under the Ministry of Justice.

div.head: An Ex Vivo Carapace-Spinal Cord Preparation

p.s: Red-eared turtles (Trachemys scripta elegans), 10-to 15-cm carapace length, were obtained from Nasco (Fort Atkinson, WI).
Surgical procedures were described before (Guzulaitis et al. 2013).
Briefly, turtles (n ϭ 29) of either sex were placed on crushed ice 2 h before surgery to induce drowsiness and reduce stress and pain by hypother-mia.
In this way, the head and neck could be protracted using minimal force.
Brain functions were terminated immediately on decapitation by crushing the head.

The blood was substituted by perfusion through the heart with a Ringer solution containing, in mM, 100 NaCl, 5 KCl, 30 NaHCO 3 , 2 MgCl 2 , 3 CaCl 2 , and 10 glucose saturated with 95% O 2 -5% CO 2 to obtain pH 7.4.
Transverse cuts were made at D9 -10 and D3 spinal cord segments (Fig. 1A).
The HF nerve innervating puboischiofemoralis internus, pars anteroventralis muscle was exposed and cut.
Scratching was initiated by mechanically stimulating turtle carapace (M8.5-M9.5)
with a fire-polished glass rod mounted to the membrane of a loudspeaker controlled with a function generator (loudspeaker in Fig. 1A).
Only responses with Ն3 bursts in HF nerve were used for analysis.
Whole cell recordings from motoneurons were performed with a MultiClamp 700B amplifier (Molecular Devices).
Patch pipettes were filled with solution containing, in mM, 122 K-gluconate, 2.5 MgCl 2 , 5.6 Mg-gluconate, 5 K-HEPES, 5 H-HEPES, 5 Na 2 ATP, 1 EGTA, 0.3 CaCl 2 , and 2.5 biocytin.
pH was adjusted to 7.4 with KOH.
The electrode resistance was 4 -6 M⍀.
VC experiments were performed on neurons with low access resistance (R a Ͻ 20 M⍀) and compensated by 60 -80%.

Recordings were sampled at 20 kHz with a 16-bit analog-to-digital converter (Digidata 1322A; Molecular Devices), displayed by means of AxoScope and Clampex software (Molecular Devices), and stored on a hard disk for later analysis.
The electroneurogram of the HF nerve was recorded with a differential amplifier, Iso-DAM8 (World Precision Instruments, Sarasota, FL), using a suction electrode.
The bandwidth was 100 Hz to 1 kHz.
Motoneurons were identified by their location in the ventral horn, size (as indicated by membrane resistance), and height of action potentials.
Recordings were accepted if motoneurons had a stable membrane potential (V m ) more negative than Ϫ50 mV and were not firing at rest.
A subset (n ϭ 20) of neurons in the ex vivo preparation were filled with biocytin for histological processing (Fig. 1B).

Lumbar segments were removed en bloc from the ex vivo preparation, kept in phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) with 4% paraformaldehyde for 24 -48 h at 4°C, and subsequently rinsed with and stored in PBS.
Fixed spinal segments were mounted in an agar mount and sectioned transversely into 100-m-thick slices using a microtome (Leica VT1000 S).

The slices were incubated in a blocking solution (PBS ϩ 0.1% Triton X-100 ϩ 5% donkey serum) for 4 h at 4°C and later for 24 -48 h at 4°C with a goat polyclonal antibody directed against choline acetyltransferase (1:250; Millipore).

The slices were washed three times with PBS ϩ 0.1% Triton X-100 and incubated for 12-24 h at 4°C with secondary antibodies Alexa Fluor 647 conjugated with donkey anti-goat antibodies (1:500; Jackson ImmunoResearch) and cyanine 3 (Cy3) conjugated to streptavidin (1:500; Jackson Immu-noResearch).
After three washes with PBS, the slices were mounted and coverslipped using ProLong Gold antifade reagent (Invitrogen) and cured overnight at 4°C before microscopy.
Micrographs of neurons were produced using a confocal microscope, Zeiss LSM 700, with diode lasers, on a Zeiss Axio Imager M2 using ϫ20/0.8-numerical
aperture Plan-Apochromat objective (Zeiss).
The fluorophores were excited/detected at the following: Cy3 at 555/560 -800 nm and Alexa Fluor 647 at 643/560 -800 nm.
Images were handled with ZEN 2011 software (Zeiss) in the LSM and 8-bit TIFF format.

div.head: Data Analysis

p.s: Motoneuron classification.
Motoneurons were categorized based on how their V m related to motor output during scratch network activity.
To find the relationship, the HF nerve activity was rectified and both V m and the rectified HF nerve activity were low-pass filtered (5-Hz Gaussian; Fig. 1).
The correlation (Pearson) was calculated between the filtered signals.
A set of data from HF motoneurons (n ϭ 20) was presented in a previous paper (Guzulaitis and Hounsgaard 2017) with additional analysis applied in this study.
Relationship between synaptic activity and motor nerve output.
HF nerve activity was rectified, and both intracellular recordings (V m or synaptic current) and rectified HF nerve activity were low-pass filtered (5-Hz Gaussian; Fig. 2).
The correlation between synaptic input and motor output was evaluated when motoneurons were recorded at Ϫ65 mV (Fig. 2C) and at 0 mV (Fig. 2E).
For convenience, the inward current recorded at Ϫ65 mV was inverted.
The inward current recorded at Ϫ65 mV was considered to be excitatory synaptic input, and outward current recorded at 0 mV was considered to be inhibitory synaptic input.
The correlation (Pearson) between synaptic current and nerve activity was evaluated at 0 time lag (histograms in Fig. 2, C and E) and other time lags (Fig. 2, D and F).
Normalization of intracellular recordings.
First, intracellular records were normalized in time.
To do so, V m , but not membrane current (I m ), was low-pass filtered (5-Hz Gaussian) and normalized with respect to HF nerve activity (Fig. 5).
To determine the onset and offset of HF bursts, the electroneurographic activity was rectified and low-pass filtered (5-Hz Gaussian).
The onset of HF activity was defined as 0 (or 1) and the offset as 0.5.
The intracellular signal (V m or I m ) during the active and the quiescence HF phases were divided into 100 equal segments each, and the mean of Ն3 successive scratch cycles was calculated.
The correlation (Pearson) between current recorded at Ϫ65 and 0 mV was calculated (Fig. 5F).
Next, intensities of both V m and synaptic current were normalized to peak levels.
Regularity of firing.
The firing of motoneurons was evaluated by calculating interspike interval (ISI) between two adjacent action potentials (APs).
Only recordings of motoneurons with Ͼ30 APs were used, and only ISIs within motor bursts were included in the analysis.
The ratio of adaptation/acceleration was calculated as a ratio between adapting (ISIϩ1 Ͼ ISI) and accelerating (ISIϩ1 Ͻ ISI) ISI pairs and referred to as the adaptation index.
The irregularity of spiking was evaluated using coefficient of variation, also known as CV 2 (Holt et al. 1996;Eq. 1):

div.formula: CV 2 ϭ 2 Խ ISI Ϫ ISI ϩ1Խ ISI ϩ ISI ϩ1 . (1

p.s: CV 2 was calculated for each pair of APs and averaged across multiple scratch cycles.
V m and synaptic input in HF and HE motoneurons during scratching.
First, the amplitude of the V m modulation during scratching was examined in HF and HE motoneurons.
The amplitude was determined from normalized intracellular recordings by subtracting hyperpolarized V m during the trough of the scratch cycle from peak V m during depolarization (Fig. 6C).

Next, the resting conductance of HF and HE motoneurons was compared from the conductance estimated from the current-voltage relationship obtained from the voltage response to current pulses in a range of intensities injected into the cells at rest (Fig. 6D).
Finally, the peak inhibitory and excitatory synaptic current was determined from normalized and averaged VC recordings during scratch cycles and compared between motoneuron groups (Fig. 6, E and F).
In addition, the ratio of inhibition and excitation was evaluated from the peaks of synaptic current at Ϫ65 and 0 mV during successive scratch episodes (Fig. 6G).
V m and synaptic input in HF and HF-like motoneurons during scratching.
Peaks of V m and synaptic current were determined from the normalized and averaged scratch cycles (Fig. 7).
Next, timing of the peaks was used to compare V m and synaptic input to HF and HF-like motoneurons.
HE motoneurons during ipsilateral and contralateral scratching.
V m and excitatory and inhibitory current in HE motoneurons were recorded during both ipsilateral (Fig. 9A) and contralateral scratching (Fig. 9B).
Peaks of V m during contralateral scratching were normalized to peaks of V m during ipsilateral scratching (Fig. 9D).
The same normalization was applied for excitatory (Fig. 9E) and inhibitory current (Fig. 9F).

Data were analyzed statistically using two-tailed Wilcoxon signedrank test for paired comparison and two-tailed Mann-Whitney test for independent samples (Origin software; OriginLab, Northampton, MA).
Data are presented as means (SD).
Mechanical stimulation in the hindlimb scratch receptive field of the turtle carapace induces scratchlike rhythmic activity in the HF nerve (Fig. 1, C-E).
The period of the scratch rhythm varied from 0.7 to 4.9 s with mean of 2.26 (0.75) s (n ϭ 450 scratch cycles).
The motoneurons recorded (n ϭ 50) were divided into one of three classes according to how well changes in V m correlated with HF motor nerve activity during scratching (Fig. 1).
Motoneurons with a high correlation coefficient between V m and HF nerve activity (r Ͼ 0.8) were catego-rized as HF motoneurons (n ϭ 20; Fig. 1C).
Motoneurons with a lower but positive correlation between V m and nerve activity (0 Ͻ r Ͻ 0.8) were categorized as HF-like motoneurons (n ϭ 17; Fig. 1D).
The remaining motoneurons with negative correlation between V m and nerve activity were categorized as HE motoneurons (n ϭ 13; Fig. 1E).
The population of motoneurons recorded in this study is summarized in Fig. 1F.

div.head: Excitation and Inhibition in Spinal Motoneurons during Scratching

p.s: After recording V m during scratching (Fig. 2A), excitatory and inhibitory synaptic current were recorded during subsequent scratch episodes.
First, the excitatory synaptic input was recorded as the inward current at Ϫ65 mV during a scratch episode (Fig. 2C).
Note that inward current recorded at Ϫ65 mV is inverted.
Next, the inhibitory synaptic input was recorded as the outward current at 0 mV during scratching (Fig. 2E).
The correlation between HF nerve activity and intracellular recording in HF motoneurons was evaluated (histograms in Fig. 2, A, C, and E).
Next, the correlation between V m and HF nerve activity at different time lags was determined (Fig. 2B), and the peak correlation was identified.
For HF motoneurons, the correlation peak [0.93 (0.04), n ϭ 20] occurred close to 0 time lag [0.01 (0.02), n ϭ 20; Fig. 2B, right].
The correlation between excitatory current and nerve activity [0.84 (0.12), n ϭ 20] also peaked close to 0 time lag [Ϫ0.001 (0.02), n ϭ 20; Fig. 2D, right].

Finally, the correlation between inhibitory current and nerve activity was evaluated, and a negative correlation peak [Ϫ0.76 (0.12), n ϭ 20] was found close to 0 time lag [Ϫ0.002 (0.1), n ϭ 20], whereas a positive peak [0.62 (0.12), n ϭ 20] was observed when inhibitory current was delayed or advanced by half of a cycle (Fig. 2F, right).
To summarize, HF motoneurons receive in-phase excitatory synaptic input, whereas inhibitory synaptic input occurs out of phase.
The same procedure was applied for HF-like motoneurons (Fig. 3).

Even though the correlation between V m and nerve activity was quite low for HF-like motoneurons at 0 time lag The correlation between HF nerve activity and intracellular recordings of HE motoneurons was also evaluated (Fig. 4).
In HE motoneurons, V m and HF nerve activity were negatively correlated during scratching [Ϫ0.68 (0.17

div.head: Relation among V m , APs, Excitation, and Inhibition in Spinal Motoneurons

p.s: To relate V m , APs, excitation, and inhibition with each other, intracellular records were normalized in time with respect to HF nerve activity (Fig. 5).
The majority of the recorded motoneurons (35 out of 50 motoneurons) fired APs during scratching as shown in Figs.
The cumulative histogram of APs fired by HF motoneurons during scratching (histogram in top of Fig. 5A) is closely related to V m (top traces of Fig. 5A).
A similar close relation between firing and V m was observed in HE motoneurons (top of Fig. 5B) and HF-like motoneurons (top of Fig. 5C).

Close relation between V m and firing in recorded motoneurons is further supported by the finding that timing of the peak of V m during scratching is well-correlated (r ϭ 0.96, P ϭ 6EϪ14; n ϭ 25) to the timing of maximal firing (Fig. 5D).
Out-of-phase excitation and inhibition was observed in most HF and HE motoneurons (Fig. 5, A and B), whereas some overlap between inhibition and excitation was found in HF-like motoneurons (Fig. 5C).
The correlation between excitation and inhibition was Ϫ0.59 (0.32; n ϭ 20) for HF motoneurons and Ϫ0.65 (0.17; n ϭ 13) for HE motoneurons (Fig. 5F).
The correlation between excitation and inhibition in HF-like motoneurons varied from positive to negative with a mean of 0.06 (0.5; n ϭ 17; Fig. 5F).
Previous studies showed that motoneurons fire irregularly during scratching (Berg et al. 2008;Guzulaitis et al. 2016) and swimming (Guzulaitis et al. 2016).
Motoneurons recorded in this study demonstrated similar irregular firing indicated by CV 2 [0.46 (0.13), n ϭ 25] as in a previous study (Guzulaitis et al. 2016).
In addition, the adaptation index [1.01
(0.16), n ϭ 25] indicates that there is no clear acceleration or adaptation in firing rates during scratching.

Irregular firing suggests that spike activity is mainly driven by excitatory synaptic input as supported by the fact that maximal firing in recorded motoneurons is closely correlated with a peak of excitatory input (r ϭ 0.97, P ϭ 2.4EϪ15; n ϭ 25; Fig. 5E).

div.head: V m and Patterns of Synaptic Input in HF and HE Motoneurons

p.s: Mean V m and mean synaptic current are in Fig. 6A, left, for HF motoneurons (n ϭ 20) and in Fig. 6B, left, for HE motoneurons (n ϭ 13).

V m modulation during scratching was of similar amplitude in the two groups of motoneurons [17.86 (7.29) mV, n ϭ 20 for HF motoneurons and 18.16 (5.74) mV, n ϭ 13 for HE motoneurons; P ϭ 0.9, Mann-Whitney test; Fig. 6C].

Excitatory input, i.e., current recorded in VC mode at Ϫ65 mV, peaked at higher levels in HF motoneurons [2.42 (1.58) nA, n ϭ 20] than in HE motoneurons [1.08 (0.51) nA, n ϭ 13; P ϭ 0.002, Mann-Whitney test; Fig. 6E].

This could at least in part be explained by the fact that membrane conductance at rest in HF motoneurons [68.86 (30.58) nS, n ϭ 20] is higher than membrane conductance in HE motoneurons [37.42 (26.09), n ϭ 13; P ϭ 0.0016, Mann-Whitney test; Fig. 6D], meaning that more current is needed to depolarize HF motoneurons to the same V m level.
Inhibitory input, i.e., current recorded in VC mode at 0 mV, peaked at lower levels in HF motoneurons [2.35 (1.47) nA, n ϭ 20] than in HE motoneurons [3.57
(2.02) nA, n ϭ 13; P ϭ 0.047, Mann-Whitney test; Fig. 6F].
This means that even though less inhibition is needed to hyperpolarize HE motoneurons with lower membrane conductance, they, nevertheless, receive much stronger inhibitory input during scratching.
Finally, the ratio between synaptic current peaks was calculated and compared between groups of motoneurons.
The ratio between inhibitory and excitatory current peaks was lower in HF motoneurons [1.04 (0.42), n ϭ 20] than in HE motoneurons [3.7 (2.28), n ϭ 13; P ϭ 6.6EϪ8, Mann-Whitney test; Fig. 6G].
To sum up, HE motoneurons receive much stronger inhibition than HF motoneurons during scratching.
Next, the relationships between excitatory and inhibitory input to V m were plotted in Fig. 6A, right, for HF motoneurons (n ϭ 20) and in Fig. 6B, right, for HE motoneurons (n ϭ 13).

Hysteresis was observed for excitatory input in both HF (Fig. 6A) and HE motoneurons (Fig. 6B), indicating that the same V m levels in motoneurons are obtained with more excitation during depolarization than during hyperpolarization.

Similar hysteresis was observed for inhibitory input in HF motoneurons (Fig. 6A), i.e., a fairly linear relation between V m and inhibitory current was observed during hyperpolarization fol-lowed by a decrease in inhibition, whereas V m stayed the same and only little inhibition remained during depolarization.
A different pattern of inhibition was observed in HE motoneurons (Fig. 6B) with more inhibition during depolarization than during hyperpolarization.
In addition, it is clear from the plot that V m hyperpolarizes early before inhibition peaks and the subsequent increase in inhibition does not affect V m much.
This confirms the seemingly excessive inhibitory input observed in HE motoneurons.

div.head: V m and Patterns of Synaptic Input in HF-Like Motoneurons

p.s: As seen in Fig. 5C, inhibition and excitation clearly overlap in HF-like motoneurons.
However, it is also obvious that inhibition does not peak at the same time as excitation but rather is time-shifted so that inhibition leads excitation.
To highlight the difference between HF and HF-like motoneurons, the signals were superimposed in Fig. 7.
The excitatory input is very similar in these two classes of motoneurons (Fig. 7C) 7D].
Note, however, that the V m depolarization is delayed in HF-like motoneurons (Fig. 7, A and B).
HF motoneurons depolarize maximally early during the scratch cycle [0.28
(0.06), n ϭ 20], whereas HF-like motoneurons depolarize gradually to reach maximal depolarization later during the scratch cycle [0.35
(0.07), n ϭ 17; P ϭ 0.004, Mann-Whitney test].
The gradual depolarization is most likely due to the pattern of inhibition (Fig. 7E).
Inhibition in HF-like motoneurons peaks just before the onset of depolarization [0.24 (0.21), n ϭ 17] and gradually subsides during the excitatory phase as V m depolarization develops.
In contrast inhibition in HF motoneurons peaks out of phase with V m depolarization and excitation [0.59 (0.17), n ϭ 20; P ϭ 9.8EϪ6, Mann-Whitney test; Fig. 7F].
The role of inhibition in HF-like motoneurons was explored in an additional experiment.
First, the pattern of firing and V m were recorded in current-clamp mode in HF and HF-like motoneurons (Fig. 8, A and E).
The excitatory input was then recorded in VC mode at Ϫ65 mV in each motoneuron.
This current was inverted and, in the absence of network activity, injected back to the motoneurons from which it was recorded (Fig. 8, B and F).
All motoneurons (n ϭ 17) showed rhythmic firing and/or depolarizations of V m in response to the injected excitatory current obtained during scratching (Fig. 8, C and G).
Qualitatively similar firing and/or V m pattern during scratching and current injection were observed in HF motoneurons (n ϭ 10; Fig. 8D).
In contrast, early firing and/or V m depolarization was seen when HF-like motoneurons (n ϭ 7) were stimulated by excitatory input (Fig. 8H).
This supports the idea that inhibition in HF-like motoneurons delays depolarization of V m and firing during scratching.

div.head: Synaptic Activity in HE Motoneurons during Ipsi-and Contralateral Scratching

p.s: Our experiments confirm that periods of synaptic inhibition and excitation alternate in both HF and HE motoneurons during scratching.
Next, we investigated the sensitivity of this pattern to changes in network activity.
Even though scratching is a predominantly unilateral behavior, the contralateral hindlimb is also involved (Field and Stein 1997).

Both HE and HF motoneurons are activated during ipsilateral scratching, whereas mainly HE but not HF motoneurons are active during contralateral scratching (Currie and Gonsalves 1997;Guzulaitis et al. 2014).
Therefore, HE motoneuron was recorded during both ipsilateral (Fig. 9A) and contralateral (Fig. 9B) scratch episodes.
As expected, HE motoneuron was activated during both ipsilateral and contralateral scratching (top of Fig. 9, A-C).

The intensity of excitatory current was similar during ipsilateral and contralateral scratching (middle of Fig. 9, A-C), whereas inhibition was much weaker during contralateral scratching than during ipsilateral scratching (bottom of Fig. 9, A-C).
This pattern was observed for all 11 HE motoneurons recorded during ipsilateral and contralateral scratching.
V m depolarized slightly less during contralateral scratching [0.84 (0.23), n ϭ 11; P ϭ 0.02, Wilcoxon signed-rank test] than during ipsilateral scratching (Fig. 9D).
In line, weaker excitatory input [0.71 (0.23), n ϭ 11; P ϭ 0.005, Wilcoxon signed-rank test] was observed during contralateral scratching (Fig. 9E).

However, the most noticeable difference was be- tween inhibitory input during different behaviors in that inhibition was much weaker [0.43 (0.28), n ϭ 11; P ϭ 0.002, Wilcoxon signed-rank test] during contralateral scratching than during ipsilateral scratching (Fig. 9F).
Despite differences in synaptic intensity during the two behaviors, the phase relations were unaffected.
Inhibition and excitation were out of phase during both ipsilateral [Ϫ0.66 (0.18), n ϭ 11] and contralateral scratching [Ϫ0.75 (0.08), n ϭ 11; P ϭ 0.15, Wilcoxon signed-rank test; Fig. 9G].
Patterns of excitatory and inhibitory synaptic input were investigated in spinal motoneurons during scratch network activity in an ex vivo preparation from the adult turtle.
Outof-phase excitation and inhibition was demonstrated for both HF and HE motoneurons during ipsilateral scratching and for HE motoneurons during contralateral scratching.

Alternation between flexors and extensors during rhythmic motor behaviors is commonly attributed to reciprocal inhibition between antagonistic half-centers and predicts that excitation and inhibition alternate in flexor and extensor motoneurons (Goulding et al. 2014;Grillner and Jessell 2009;Kiehn 2016;Stein 2010).

However, out-of-phase excitation and inhibition in motoneurons has only been explicitly demonstrated in aquatic vertebrates where axial movements are produced by alternating activity between left and right sides (Dale 1985;Gabriel et al. 2009;Russell and Wallén 1983).

The mecha-nisms responsible for left-right alternation during axial rhythmic movements in aquatic vertebrates are not necessarily the same as the ones securing alternation between flexors and extensors in limbed vertebrates.
First, coordination between flexor-extensor and left-right develop at different embryonic stages (Kudo et al. 2004).

Second, commissural interneurons are crucial for left-right coordination both in aquatic (Moult et al. 2013) and limbed animals (Butt and Kiehn 2003;Talpalar et al. 2013), whereas flexor-extensor coordination is well-preserved in hemisegments (Kudo and Yamada 1987;Zhong et al. 2012).

The first direct demonstration of out-of-phase excitation and inhibition in limbed vertebrates was recently obtained from HF motoneurons during scratch network activity in the turtle (Guzulaitis and Hounsgaard 2017).
The present study extends and confirms out-of-phase excitation and inhibition to apply for HE motoneurons during ipsi-and contralateral network activity.

Thus, although the networks that secure alternation between ipsilateral flexors and extensors and left and right limbs are different, motoneurons are driven by out-of-phase excitation and inhibition in both cases.

Probably because of lack of direct experimental support, the classic reciprocal inhibition in spinal motor function was challenged when high-conductance states were observed in turtle spinal motoneurons during rhythmic network activity (Alaburda et al. 2005;Guzulaitis et al. 2016).

It is known that high-conductance states in cortical neurons are the outcome of concurrent excitation and inhibition (Destexhe et al. 2003;Shu et al. 2003; Wilent and Contreras 2005), and, indeed, concurrent excitation and inhibition was proposed also to explain conductance increase in HF motoneurons during rhythmic network activity (Berg et al. 2007).

However, a recent study showed that intrinsic conductance in spinal motoneurons contributes significantly to the conductance increase during network activity and that neglecting this intrinsic conductance leads to overestimation of in-phase inhibition (Guzulaitis and Hounsgaard 2017).
In fact, the study showed that the outward current that balances excitation in HF motoneurons during scratching is predominantly generated by intrinsic conductance rather than synaptic inhibition.
This selfcompensatory in-built mechanism may secure V m stabilization near threshold for action potential during intense synaptic excitation.

In addition, out-of-phase synaptic excitation and inhibition was explicitly demonstrated in HF motoneurons in the adult turtle during scratch network activity (Guzulaitis and Hounsgaard 2017) and confirmed for HE motoneurons in this study.
These findings support reciprocal rather than concurrent activation of spinal motoneurons during rhythmic behaviors.
Ia inhibitory interneurons are likely candidates for reciprocal inhibition and alternation between flexors and extensors in the spinal cord (Hultborn 1976;Jankowska et al. 1965).

These neurons are derived from V1 and V2b inhibitory interneurons, and alternation between extensors and flexors is abolished after inactivation of V1 and V2b interneurons in mouse spinal cord (Zhang et al. 2014).
In addition, Ia interneurons are highly active when their target motoneurons are inhibited (Geertsen et al. 2011).
However, Ia interneurons do not fire only when their target motoneurons are inhibited.
They are active throughout the locomotion cycle with substantial activity during motoneuron depolarization (Geertsen et al. 2011;Pratt and Jordan 1987).

Together with the activation pattern of Renshaw inhibitory interneurons (Pratt and Jordan 1987), it is not surprising that inhibitory synaptic activity is present even during mo- toneuron depolarization and firing (Alaburda et al. 2005;Guzulaitis and Hounsgaard 2017;Guzulaitis et al. 2016).
Asymmetry in synaptic input between HF and HE motoneurons was observed in this study with inhibition dominating in HE motoneurons.
In the neonatal mouse, inhibition also exceeds excitation in HE motoneurons during rhythmic network activity (Endo and Kiehn 2008).
The low level of inhibition in HE motoneurons during contralateral scratching in the turtle may suggest that this asymmetry is behavior dependent.
Despite the asymmetry observed, both HF and HE are activated in a robust push-pull manner in which inhibition alternates with excitation.
However, substantial overlap between excitation and inhibition was detected in HF-like motoneurons.
Inhibition in HF-like motoneurons led excitation and delayed depolarization of V m during rhythmic motor output.

This pattern of excitation and inhibition first reported for turtle motoneurons in vivo (Robertson and Stein 1988) was proposed to determine the recruitment order of motoneurons to form motor patterns.

Indeed, blocking inhibition in the lumbar enlargement changes the pattern of motor nerve activity, suggesting that inhibition shapes motor output by delaying activity in motoneurons (Currie and Lee 1997).
Overlap between inhibition and excitation has also been seen in zebrafish spinal motoneurons (Kishore et al. 2014) but with excitation leading inhibition.
In cortical neurons, excitation followed by inhibition may be a design to increase temporal precision of spike generation (Wehr and Zador 2003).

During scratch network activity, HF and HF-like motoneurons receive common synaptic excitation, whereas differential synaptic inhibition may serve to fine-tune the activity of each group of motoneurons separately.
This may be a way of coordinating different motor pools in a taskspecific manner.

To summarize, the majority of spinal motoneurons are driven by out-of-phase excitation and inhibition, and, even in case of overlap between inhibition and excitation as in HF-like motoneurons, their peaks are time-shifted (see Fig. 7).
Activation of HE motoneurons was studied during two different behaviors.
Although the amplitude of V m modulation was very similar during ipsilateral and contralateral scratching, the underlying intensity of synaptic input was strikingly different.
Synaptic inhibition was much stronger in ipsilateral scratching than during contralateral scratching.
Since the level of excitation is very low in the hyperpolarizing phase of both scratch forms, the functional significance of the difference in the pattern of inhibition is obscure.
It is interesting to note that the difference is not reflected in the voltage trajectory.
In fact, inhibition peaks late in the hyperpolarizing phase when V m is already stabilized rather than during the shift from the depolarized to the hyperpolarized phase (see Fig. 6B).

Since V m in HE motoneurons can be successfully hyperpolarized with moderate intensity of inhibition as seen during contralateral scratching, the function of a surplus inhibition during ipsilateral scratching is not clear.
It may possibly be a consequence of an in-built robust reciprocal inhibition between HF and HE modules.

This is supported by the intense inhibition in HE motoneurons during ipsilateral scratching when the HF module (and HF nerve) is active and the low level of inhibition during contralateral scratching when HF module is almost silent.
Furthermore, rhythmic activity in HF and HF-like motoneurons was obtained when these motoneurons were stimulated by excitatory current alone (see Fig. 8).
Therefore, inhibitory input in motoneurons is not simply to hyperpolarize V m but probably provides coordination within a motor pool (Robertson and Stein 1988) and among different motor pools.
Fig. 1.
Experimental paradigm.
A: whole cell recordings from motoneurons in an ex vivo spinal cord-carapace preparation from the adult turtle.
Mechanical stimulation (stim) of the carapace (loudspeaker) was used to induce rhythmic scratch network activity.
Network activity was monitored by electroneurographic recording from the hip flexor (HF) motor nerve.
B: subset (n ϭ 20) of the presumed motoneurons recorded from (red) were filled with biocytin for histological verification.
These neurons, recorded in the lateral part of the ventral horn, turned out to be choline acetyltransferase (ChAT)-positive cells, i.e., motoneurons.
C: intracellular recording of a HF motoneuron, i.e., motoneuron with high correlation (r Ͼ 0.8) between membrane potential (V m ) and HF nerve activity during scratching.
D: intracellular recording of a HF-like motoneuron, i.e., motoneuron with low positive correlation (0 Ͼ r Ͼ 0.8) between V m and HF nerve activity during scratching.
E: intracellular recording of a hip extensor (HE) motoneuron, i.e., motoneuron with negative correlation (r Ͻ 0) between V m and HF nerve activity during scratching.
F: histogram of correlation coefficients between V m and HF nerve activity during scratching for all recorded motoneurons (n ϭ 50).
C-E from the top: V m of motoneurons and HF nerve activity.
Light color traces depict the raw signals, and dark color traces depict the low-pass-filtered signals.
Note that the neuron shown in B was classified as HF-like motoneuron.
Fig. 2. Membrane potential (V m ) and synaptic input in hip flexor (HF) spinal motoneurons.
A: whole cell recording from a HF motoneuron during scratching.
Both V m and electroneurogram of the HF nerve activity (gray traces) were low-pass filtered (black traces), and the correlation (Pearson) between the filtered signals was calculated.
Correlation coefficients for all HF motoneurons (n ϭ 20) are shown in the histogram to the right.
B: correlation coefficient between the low-pass-filtered signals was calculated at different time lags (left), and the positive peak was identified (black arrow).
Correlation peaks were high in all HF motoneurons and occurred close to 0 time lag (right; n ϭ 20).
C: the same HF motoneuron was recorded in voltage-clamp (VC) mode at Ϫ65 mV during scratching, and signals were low-pass filtered.
Inward current recorded at Ϫ65 mV was inverted and interpreted as excitatory synaptic input.
Correlation between excitatory synaptic current and HF nerve activity was calculated for all HF motoneurons (n ϭ 20).
D: correlation between excitatory synaptic current and HF nerve activity was calculated at different time lags (left), and a positive peak of the correlation function was identified (red arrow).
High positive correlation peaks between excitatory input and HF activity were detected in all HF motoneurons, and correlations peaked around 0 time lag (right).
E: finally, the same HF motoneuron was recorded in VC mode at 0 mV during scratching.
Outward current recorded at 0 mV was interpreted as inhibitory input.
Membrane current (I m ) and HF nerve activity were low-pass filtered, and the correlation between the filtered signals was calculated (histogram to the right).
F: correlation between inhibitory current and HF nerve activity was calculated at different time lags (left).
The most positive (light blue arrow) and the most negative peaks (dark blue arrow) of the correlation function were identified.

Negative peaks of the correlation between inhibition and HF nerve activity occur close to 0 time lag, whereas positive peaks of correlation occur close to half of the scratch cycle (either Ϫ0.5 or 0.5 of scratch cycle).
A, C, and E from the top: V m (A) or I m recorded at Ϫ65 mV (C) and 0 mV (E) and HF nerve activity.
Light color traces depict raw signals, and dark color traces depict low-pass-filtered signals.
Black arrows indicate the resting V m or holding I m level before scratching.
Fig.2D, right].

Finally, the correlation between inhibitory current and nerve activity was evaluated, and a negative correlation peak [Ϫ0.76 (0.12), n ϭ 20] was found close to 0 time lag [Ϫ0.002 (0.1), n ϭ 20], whereas a positive peak [0.62 (0.12), n ϭ 20] was observed when inhibitory current was delayed or advanced by half of a cycle (Fig.2F, right).
To summarize, HF motoneurons receive in-phase excitatory synaptic input, whereas inhibitory synaptic input occurs out of phase.The same procedure was applied for HF-like motoneurons (Fig.3).
Even though the correlation between V m and nerve activity was quite low for HF-like motoneurons at 0 time lag[0.6
(0.19), n ϭ 17; Fig. 3A], the correlation peaked at 0.83 (0.06; n ϭ 17) with a positive time lag [0.1 (0.07), n ϭ 17; Fig. 3B, right].
This indicates that V m is well-correlated with HF nerve activity but delayed with respect to the HF nerve activity.

The correlation between excitatory input and HF nerve activity peaked [0.86 (0.07), n ϭ 17] close to 0 time lag [0.02 (0.07), n ϭ 17; Fig. 3D, right], showing that excitation in HF-like motoneurons is locked to HF nerve activity.
Finally, the negative peak of correlation between inhibitory current and HF nerve activity [Ϫ0.63 (0.18), n ϭ 17] is delayed by a quarter of the scratch cycle [0.28
(0.13), n ϭ 17; Fig. 3F, right], and the positive peak [0.71 (0.14), n ϭ 17] is also shifted by a quarter of the scratch cycle [Ϫ0.22

To sum up, both excitatory and inhibitory input in HF-like motoneurons are highly related to motor output, and the interplay between them gives rise to a delayed depolarization of V m .The correlation between HF nerve activity and intracellular recordings of HE motoneurons was also evaluated (Fig.4).
In HE motoneurons, V m and HF nerve activity were negatively correlated during scratching [Ϫ0.68 (0.17), n ϭ 13; Fig. 4A] and peaked near 0 time lag [Ϫ0.06 (0.06), n ϭ 13; Fig. 4B, right].
Excitatory synaptic activity correlated negatively with nerve activity [Ϫ0.45 (0.23), n ϭ 13; Fig. 4C], peaking at Ϫ0.12 (0.06) time lag (n ϭ 13; Fig. 4D, right), whereas
), n ϭ 13; Fig. 4A] and peaked near 0 time lag [Ϫ0.06 (0.06), n ϭ 13; Fig. 4B, right].
Excitatory synaptic activity correlated negatively with nerve activity [Ϫ0.45 (0.23), n ϭ 13; Fig. 4C], peaking at Ϫ0.12 (0.06) time lag (n ϭ 13; Fig. 4D, right), whereas
Fig. 3. Membrane potential (V m ) and synaptic input in hip flexor (HF)-like spinal motoneurons.
A: whole cell recording from a HF-like motoneuron during scratching.
Both V m and electroneurogram of the HF nerve activity (light green traces) were low-pass filtered (dark green traces), and the correlation (Pearson) between the filtered signals was calculated.
Correlation coefficients for all HF-like motoneurons (n ϭ 17) are shown in the histogram to the right.
B: correlation coefficient between the low-pass-filtered signals was calculated at different time lags, and positive peaks were considered (arrow).
C: the same HF-like motoneuron was recorded at Ϫ65 mV during a subsequent scratch episode, and signals were low-pass filtered.
Inward current recorded at Ϫ65 mV was inverted and interpreted as excitatory synaptic input.
Correlation between excitatory synaptic current and HF nerve activity was calculated for all HF-like motoneurons (n ϭ 17).
D: correlation between excitatory synaptic current and HF nerve activity was calculated at different time lags, and positive peaks of the correlation function were considered (arrow).
E: finally, the motoneuron was recorded at 0 mV during scratching, and outward current recorded at 0 mV was interpreted as inhibitory synaptic input.
Membrane current (I m ) and HF nerve activity were low-pass filtered, and correlation between the filtered signals was calculated for all HF-like motoneurons (n ϭ 17).
F: correlation between inhibitory current and the HF nerve activity was calculated at different time lags.
The most positive (light blue arrow) and the most negative peaks (dark blue arrow) were considered.
A, C, and E from the top: V m (A) or I m recorded at Ϫ65 mV (C) and 0 mV (E) and HF nerve activity.
Light color traces depict the raw signals, and dark color traces depict low-pass-filtered signals.
Black arrows indicate the resting V m or holding I m level before scratching.
Fig. 4. Membrane potential (V m ) and synaptic input in hip extensor (HE) spinal motoneurons.
A: whole cell recording from a HE motoneuron during scratching.

Both V m and electroneurogram of the hip flexor (HF) nerve activity (light yellow traces) were low-pass filtered (dark yellow traces), and the correlation (Pearson) between the filtered signals was calculated.
Correlation coefficients for all HE motoneurons (n ϭ 13) are shown in the histogram to the right.
B: correlation coefficient between the low-pass-filtered signals was calculated at different time lags, and negative peaks were considered (arrow).
C: the same HE motoneuron was recorded at Ϫ65 mV during a subsequent scratch episode, and the signals were low-pass filtered.
Inward current recorded at Ϫ65 mV was inverted and interpreted as excitatory synaptic input.
Correlation between excitatory synaptic current and HF nerve activity was calculated for all HE motoneurons (n ϭ 13).
D: correlation between excitatory synaptic current and HF nerve activity was calculated at different time lags, and the negative peaks of the correlation function were considered (arrow).
E: finally, the neuron was recorded at 0 mV during scratching, and outward current recorded at 0 mV was interpreted as inhibitory synaptic input.
Membrane current (I m ) and HF nerve activity were low-pass filtered, and the correlation between the filtered signals was calculated for all HE motoneurons (n ϭ 13).
F: correlation between the inhibitory current and HF nerve activity was calculated at different time lags.
The most positive (light blue arrow) and the most negative peaks (dark blue arrow) were considered.
A, C, and E from the top: V m (A) or I m recorded at Ϫ65 mV (C) and 0 mV (E) and HF nerve activity.
Light color traces depict raw signals, and dark color traces depict low-pass-filtered signals.
Black arrows indicate the resting V m or holding I m level before scratching.
Fig. 5. Correlation between inhibition and excitation in spinal motoneurons.

Cumulative histograms are of action potentials (APs) and membrane potential (V m ; top) and excitatory (red; middle) and inhibitory (blue; bottom) current normalized with respect to hip flexor (HF) nerve activity for HF motoneurons (A), hip extensor (HE) motoneurons (B), and HF-like motoneurons (C).
D: relation between peak V m and peak firing rate (F) during scratching.
E: relation between peak excitatory current and peak firing rate during scratching.
F: negative correlation between excitatory (exc) and inhibitory (inh) current was observed in a majority of motoneurons.
Positive correlation between excitatory and inhibitory current was found in some HF-like motoneurons.
A-C from the top: cumulative histogram of APs fired during scratching, V m , membrane current (I m ) recorded at Ϫ65 mV, I m recorded at 0 mV, and HF nerve activity as a reference for scratch cycle.
Arrows show the resting V m or holding I m level before scratching.
Fig. 6.
Synaptic patterns in hip flexor (HF) and hip extensor (HE) motoneurons.
A: mean normalized membrane potential (V m ; black circles) and excitatory (red circles) and inhibitory current (blue circles) for HF motoneurons (n ϭ 20).
Relation between excitatory current and V m is shown in the top right.
Relation between inhibitory current and V m is shown in the bottom right.
B: mean of the normalized V m (yellow circles) and excitatory (red circles) and inhibitory current (blue circles) for HE motoneurons (n ϭ 13).
Relation between excitatory current and V m is shown in the top right.
Relation between inhibitory current and V m is shown in the bottom right.
Filled circles represent the depolarization phase, and open circles represent the hyperpolarization phase during scratching.
I m , membrane current.
C: V m modulation in HF motoneurons during scratching [17.86 (7.29) mV, n ϭ 20] is similar to V m modulation in HE motoneurons during scratching [18.16 (5.74) mV, n ϭ 13; P ϭ 0.9, Mann-Whitney test].
D: membrane conductance (g) of HF motoneurons [68.86 (30.58) nS, n ϭ 19] is higher than membrane conductance of HE motoneurons [37.42 (26.09) nS, n ϭ 13; P ϭ 0.0016, Mann-Whitney test].
E: peak inward current recorded at Ϫ65 mV is higher in HF motoneurons [2.42 (1.58) nA, n ϭ 20] than in HE motoneurons [1.08 (0.51) nA, n ϭ 13; P ϭ 0.002, Mann-Whitney test].
F: peak outward current recorded at 0 mV is lower in HF motoneurons [2.35 (1.47) nA, n ϭ 20] than in HE motoneurons [3.57
(2.02) nA, n ϭ 13; P ϭ 0.047, Mann-Whitney test].
G: ratio between inhibitory (inh) and excitatory (exc) current peaks is lower in HF motoneurons [1.04 (0.42), n ϭ 20] than in HE motoneurons [3.7 (2.28), n ϭ 13; P ϭ 6.6EϪ8, Mann-Whitney test].
Level of significance is indicated as not significant (ns; P Ͼ 0.05), *P Ͻ 0.05, **P Ͻ 0.01, and ***P Ͻ 0.001.
Fig. 7. Synaptic patterns in hip flexor (HF) and HF-like motoneurons.
A: superimposed mean of the normalized membrane potential (V m ) for all HF motoneurons (black; n ϭ 20) and all HF-like motoneurons (green; n ϭ 17).
B: V m in HF motoneurons peaks earlier during the scratch cycle [0.28
(0.06), n ϭ 20] than V m of HF-like motoneurons [0.35 (0.07), n ϭ 17; P ϭ 0.004, Mann-Whitney test].
C: mean of the normalized excitatory synaptic current in HF motoneurons (dark red) and HF-like motoneurons (light red).
D: excitatory synaptic current in HF motoneurons peak at the same time [0.26 (0.05), n ϭ 20] as in HF-like motoneurons [0.3 (0.09), n ϭ 17; P ϭ 0.1, Mann-Whitney test].
E: mean of the normalized inhibitory synaptic current in HF motoneurons (dark blue) and HF-like motoneurons (light blue).

F: inhibitory synaptic current in HF motoneurons peaks out of phase with V m [0.59 (0.17), n ϭ 20], whereas inhibition in HF-like motoneurons peaks slightly earlier than excitation and V m [0.24 (0.21), n ϭ 17; P ϭ 9.8EϪ6, Mann-Whitney test].
Fig. 8. Stimulation of hip flexor (HF) and HF-like motoneurons with excitatory current recorded during scratching.
A: membrane potential (V m ) of a HF motoneuron during scratching (black).
Excitatory current was recorded in voltage-clamp mode at Ϫ65 mV (light red) during a subsequent scratch episode.
This current was inverted (dark red) and injected back to recorded motoneuron in current-clamp mode in the absence of network activity.

B: expanded episodes from recordings obtained during scratching (black) and excitatory current stimulation (red) in A. C: normalized V m during scratching (gray) and excitatory current stimulation (light red) in all HF motoneurons (n ϭ 10).
D: mean normalized V m during scratching (black) and excitatory current stimulation (dark red) of all HF motoneurons (n ϭ 10).
E: V m of HF-like motoneuron during scratching (black) and excitatory current stimulation (dark red).

F: expanded episodes from recording obtained during scratching (black) and excitatory current stimulation (red) in E. G: normalized V m during scratching (gray) and excitatory current stimulation (light red) in all HF-like motoneurons (n ϭ 7).
H: mean normalized V m during scratching (black) and excitatory current stimulation (dark red) of all HF-like motoneurons (n ϭ 7).
Fig. 9. Excitation and inhibition in hip extensor (HE) motoneurons during ipsilateral and contralateral scratching.
A: membrane potential (V m ) from a HE motoneuron during ipsilateral scratching (black).
Excitatory current was recorded at Ϫ65 mV (red) and inhibitory current was recorded at 0 mV (blue) during subsequent ipsilateral scratch episodes.
Note that the excitatory current is inverted.
B: V m of the same HE motoneuron was recorded during contralateral scratching (gray).
Excitatory current recorded at Ϫ65 mV (red) and inhibitory current recorded at 0 mV (light blue) during subsequent contralateral scratch episodes.

C: normalized V m (top) and excitatory (middle) and inhibitory current (bottom) during both ipsilateral (left) and contralateral (right) scratching from the HE motoneuron shown in A and B. D: peak depolarization of V m in HE motoneurons is slightly lower during contralateral scratching [0.84 (0.22), n ϭ 11; P ϭ 0.02, Wilcoxon signed-rank test] than during ipsilateral scratching.
E: in line, the peak of excitatory input in HE motoneurons is lower during contralateral scratching [0.71 (0.23), n ϭ 11; P ϭ 0.005, Wilcoxon signed-rank test] than during ipsilateral scratching.
F: stronger inhibitory input is present during ipsilateral scratching than during contralateral scratching [0.43 (0.28), n ϭ 11; P ϭ 0.002, Wilcoxon signed-rank test].

G: no difference in correlation between excitation and inhibition in HE motoneurons during ipsilateral [Ϫ0.66 (0.18), n ϭ 11] and contralateral scratching [Ϫ0.75 (0.08), n ϭ 11; P ϭ 0.15, Wilcoxon signed-rank test], i.e., excitation is negatively correlated with inhibition.
Level of significance is indicated as not significant (ns; P Ͼ 0.05), *P Ͻ 0.05, and **P Ͻ 0.01.
cHF, contralateral hip flexor nerve; iHF, ipsilateral hip flexor nerve.
